data.text: Contents
Process for oncall pharmacist attendance on site ...................................................... 12
Introduction

The Trust pharmacy service provides comprehensive medication supply and advice during normal pharmacy opening hours. These hours are displayed on each site's inpatient pharmacy dispensary entrance/hatch.

All reasonable effort should be made to ensure medication supplies (especially routine stock items) are requested within pharmacy opening hours, negating the need to request out-of-hours. Ward/dept. staff should work closely with their pharmacy distribution/stores contact to ensure adequate supplies are available for periods when pharmacy will be closed. If there is unusual high usage this should be escalated to the pharmacy team to increase supplies during opening hours.

Outside of these hours (i.e. when the site pharmacy is closed), a range of resources are available to support all healthcare professionals in the Trust. Some external organisations may have access to limited resources in line with their Trust pharmacy service level agreement (SLA).

The aim of the oncall pharmacy service is to help with answering urgent queries regarding the prescribing, administration and obtaining of critical medicines out of hours. Oncall requests are recorded and monitored by the pharmacy directorate. Any identified practice issues are shared with clinical divisions for learning.

Unlike other oncall services that operate within the hospital, the pharmacists providing the hospital oncall service will be doing so after a full day shift. They do not reside onsite overnight. It is therefore essential that the calls they receive are ones that genuinely require their assistance, and cannot be resolved without them.
Medicines supply out of hours initially must involve obtaining medicines from speciality wards who will lend a supply, or using the emergency drug cupboard.

Each site operates an emergency drug cupboard (EDC) holding a range of medicines to access out of hours. These may be either commonly used critical medicines not routinely stocked on wards, or rarely-used medicines that may be needed in an emergency.

The EDC stock list is not exhaustive, and on occasion a critically urgent medicine is not obtainable from any other clinical area on site. In such circumstances a registrant in a clinical area may need to contact the oncall pharmacist for advice on how to proceed.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:
To provide guidance on the appropriate use of the Emergency Drug Cupboard (EDC) and the oncall pharmacist service;
signpost Trust staff to the most efficient way of obtaining emergency medicines for patients out of hours;
signpost Trust staff to medication-related advice as first option before contacting the oncall pharmacist.
Definitions

table_items.text: Emergency Drug Cupboard. A room located on each of the main hospital sites stocking a range of critical medicines that may need obtaining outside pharmacy-opening hours. May also be known as an Emergency Drug Room (EDR).

A medicine where timeliness of administration is crucial, and must NOT be omitted. Refer to the published Trust Critical Medicines List on the intranet. Includes all drugs to be given immediately or within 2 hours of due time on prescription and any drug that may have a significant short or long-term patient impact; Includes all medicines used in emergency care (i.e. crash trolley- type drugs) & treatment of overdose/poisoning since those medicines are high risk if omitted or delayed in any circumstance.
The internal ‘internet' for the Trust. At time of writing are site-specific and may be/ were known as ‘The Hub' (Basildon), ‘Staffnet' (Southend) etc.

data.text: Role & Responsibilities within the Trust
MSE Patient Safety & Quality Group
Receiving exception reports and taking action in response to issues raised from Medicines Assurance Group and/or department of pharmacy.
MSE Medicines Assurance Group
Ensuring the effective implementation, use and timely review of this policy;
Ensuring that monitoring arrangements are appropriately performed by the site Medicines Optimisation and Safety Groups (MOSG);
Where necessary, escalating concerns to the Chief Nurse / Site Director/s of Nursing or Chief Medical Officer / Site Medical Director/s as appropriate;
Exception reporting to the MSE Patient Safety & Quality Group on developments, concerns and progress concerning out of hours medication use.
Site Medicines Optimisation and Safety Group (MOSG)
Monitoring this policy through incident reports;
Escalating issues to site divisional governance groups and MAG as appropriate.
Chief Executive

As the Trust's accountable officer has overall responsibility for ensuring the Trust has robust, complete and up to date documents in place to govern and guide activities so that legal and national requirements are met.
Chief Nursing Officer, delegating to the site Directors of Nursing
Ensuring that there is policy compliance and liaising with the site Pharmacy Operational Lead, if required;
Ensuring any escalated out of hours medication issues involving professions they oversee are appropriately managed corporately.
Chief Pharmacist
Setting the overall framework and policy standards for out of hours medication across the organisation, in line with regulatory and best practice guidance;
Ensuring a monitoring process exists and functions for policy standard.
The Chief Pharmacist delegates this responsibility to the site pharmacy Head of Departments and site Pharmacy Operational Leads for delivery.
Designated Pharmacy Head of Department for clinical services
Overseeing clinical pharmacy decision making regarding oncall pharmacist activity.
This may be delegated to the site Principal Pharmacist - Clinical Services but overall responsibility for MSE-wide consistency remains with them.
Site Principal Pharmacist Clinical Services (Clinical Lead Pharmacist)

Ensuring site pharmacists are suitably trained and supported in order for them to provide the oncall service. This may be delegated to another site lead pharmacist, but overall responsibility remains with them;
Providing specific advice and decision making on the range of medicines the EDC contains, ensuring MSE-wide consistency.
Designated Pharmacy Operational Lead for oncall pharmacy services
Overall responsibility for ensuring MSE-wide consistency in provision of the EDC for all site;
Ensuring the EDC is accessible to relevant staff, meets the needs of the users and complies with Trust medication policies;
Ensuring issues related to the operational delivery of the oncall pharmacy service and EDC are regularly reviewed and escalated with appropriate actions taken.
Site Pharmacy Operational Lead
Site responsibility for ensuring the EDC is maintained by the designated site lead technician and team, adhering to MSE-wide standards at all times;
Ensuring site EDC considerations are monitored, evaluated and escalated in a timely manner to the designated Pharmacy Operational Lead for oncall pharmacy services.
Site Oncall Pharmacist
Providing an oncall service that is timely, efficient, and professional, ensuring that they keep their training up-to-date;
Maintaining records of oncall services provided in line with pharmacy departmental records;
Ensuring they have the required access to all resources to support them in the role before the beginning of each oncall session;

Ensuring concerns identified with delivering the oncall service are immediately escalated to the designated pharmacy operational manager for oncall pharmacy services or site clinical lead pharmacist as appropriate to the issue.
Designated Lead Site Technician for pharmacy stores services
Collation and analysis of emergency drug cupboard usage;
Overseeing the replenishment, stock take and expiry date checking of the emergency drug cupboard by the pharmacy department.
Registrant accessing Emergency Drug Cupboard (EDC) or contacting oncall pharmacist
Ensure this policy is adhered to when obtaining medicines and advice out of hours;
Highlighting any training needs identified to their line manager to be followed up by the site pharmacy service when next open.
Troubleshooting
Before contacting the on-call pharmacist, the staff member should always try to resolve medicine supply issues and medicine related queries themselves
Follow all steps of the Medication Queries and Supply Troubleshooting Tool (Appendix 1). Ward managers should ensure this is displayed to their staff on all wards.
Firstly establish critical need for the medication:
5.3.1 Check if the prescribed dose is due before the pharmacy re-opens?
5.3.2 Check is it critical that the patient has this medication now or can dose wait until the department is open? The critical medicines list provides a guide.
5.3.3 If NO then contact your ward pharmacy team or send the chart to pharmacy as soon as the department re-opens.
5.3.4 If YES, follow section 5.4.
Process for obtaining medicines where critical need to administer (to be followed in this order):
5.4.1 Check patients own medicines to determine if medication is available and clearly identifiable (see Trust Administration of Medicines Policy);
5.4.2 Check / ask the patient (if possible) if a relative or carer is able to bring a supply of correctly packaged and labelled medicines from home. This will be essential for
drugs such as clozapine which cannot by supplied by MSE Pharmacy because it is a specialist medicine.

5.4.3 Check if the medicine can be obtained from another ward (i.e. speciality ward). If so, arrange to collect a full container or pack. Alternatively a pack can be borrowed and then given back once a dose given from it (i.e. tablet packs). The expectation is that the ward/department will supply the medicine; except where there is a current patient on that area which requires the full amount available before pharmacy re- opens.
5.4.4 Check if the medicine is available in the Emergency Drug Cupboard (see section 6).
5.4.5 Only if all other processes have been completed above, and supply is still required, consider contacting the oncall pharmacist as per section 7.
The Emergency Drug Cupboard (EDC)
The stock list for the EDC is located on the pharmacy homepage on the intranet, and within the EDC as a minimum for all sites.
The location of medicines stocked in wards and departments can be accessed on the intranet;
Broomfield: unavailable at present. Please contact oncall pharmacist.
Basildon: The Hub> Clinical Links> Pharmacy> Pharmacy Ward Stock Lists.
Southend: Click on ‘How to find drugs when pharmacy closed' in ‘Medicines Zone' on front page of the intranet. Then enter drug in the search box.

For some medicines it is essential that the oncall pharmacist is contacted before obtaining the medicine from the EDC. Where this is required it is clearly noted on the EDC stock list. Possible reasons that discussion is needed with the oncall pharmacist are that;
The dosing regimen is complex;
The use of the drug is restricted in the Trust;
There are significant drug interactions;
Consideration of co-morbidities of the patient may be needed to ensure the drug is suitable;
There are policies for the use of the drug that need to be complied with.
Actions before going to the EDC

6.4.1  If the medicine being obtained from the EDC is not a stock item for the department/ward requiring it, the staff member accessing the EDC must have the following patient specific details to take with them: patient name, hospital number/NHS number, consultant name/initials. This may be required for documenting on the log in the EDC.
Accessing the EDC
6.5.1 Any permanent Trust registrant (i.e. nurse/midwife) with valid Trust photo ID may have access to the keys for the EDC when the main pharmacy department is closed.
6.5.2 The key to the emergency cupboard can be obtained from the site switchboard.
6.5.3 Keys must always be signed out and back in again. A log is held for this purpose at the site switchboard.
6.5.4 The security of the EDC must be respected at all times, so keys must be kept safe and the room should be secured and locked after staff leave the room.
6.5.5 The door to access the EDC is:
Broomfield: Unmarked door. Located on ground floor, on right-hand side of the inpatient pharmacy entrance doors, A block - A105.
Southend: Unmarked door. Located on ground floor, first door on left-hand side of corridor linking main hospital corridor to the Emergency department.
Basildon: Marked A/SUP/71A. It is located on Level C, opposite the female toilets which are in close proximity to the Pharmacy Prescriptions-In-hatch and the patients entry to the X-ray Department.
Selecting the medicine from the EDC

6.6.1 Whilst every effort is made by pharmacy to ensure that all the medicines stored in the EDC are within expiry date, staff removing items from the EDC must ensure that they check the expiry date of the medicine before removing. Any issues must be notified to the site pharmacy department as soon as they re-open.
6.6.2 Staff unsure how to check expiry dates should consult MSEPO-20205 Policy for Safe and Secure Storage of Medicines.
6.6.3 Always keep individual tablets, capsules, ampoules etc. within their outer containers. The staff member must take the full container as packaged on the shelf.
6.6.4 Never split an individual container because this can cause mis-selection and important drug information e.g. leaflets may be lost.
6.6.5 Never move stock around within the EDC. It is essential that staff do not impede other staff that may use the EDC in being able to locate drugs.
6.6.6 The pharmacy department is open 7 days a week and therefore staff should inform their ward pharmacy team during normal pharmacy hours if a further supply of medication is required.
Signing out the medicine using the EDC log book

6.7.1 The Emergency Drug Cupboard (EDC) log book (located in the EDC) must be completed for all drugs removed from the EDC. Failure to document the information fully will result in the EDC not being restocked properly (because it is not known what has been taken). The result of non-compliance is that items may not be available for the use of others in the future.
6.7.2 Items recorded as ‘stock' items in the Emergency Drug Cupboard (EDC) log book will be charged by pharmacy the following day to the ward cost code that has taken them.

6.7.3 Items recorded as ‘non-stock' items, and with the details of the patient and associated consultant, will be charged by pharmacy the following day to the cost code belonging to that consultant. Failure to record patient and consultant details fully may result in the ward cost code being charged for the medicine taken.
Named-patient medicines

6.8.1 Some drugs stored in the EDC are classified as ‘Named Patient Specials', and require records to be kept of the batch/lot number of the drug in addition to the details of the patient to whom it has been issued. If vials have different batch/lot numbers, both must be recorded.
6.8.2 Please refer to the named patient specials document displayed in the site EDC, EDC log book and published on the site intranet.
Leaving and securing the EDC

6.9.1 On leaving the EDR ensure that the fridge has been securely shut, and that the door to the EDR is securely locked (for sites with two locks- check the bottom lock is locked, not just the top lock). If the room is exited without the keys the door will lock via the top lock, and another set of keys will be required to re-enter the EDC. Never leave the keys in the EDC.
6.9.2 Return the EDC keys to switchboard and sign back in immediately after use.

Prior to administration of the medication to the patient, a second suitably qualified registered healthcare professional at ward/department level must double check the medicine expiry date and description match what the patient has been prescribed. This must be in line with the Trust Administration of Medicines Policy.
The Pharmacist Oncall Service
The pharmacy directorate provides a 24/7 service to the wards across the Trust by way of an oncall service when the department is closed.
The oncall pharmacist is available for the following services:
Telephone advice regarding medication prescribing, administration and supply;
Requests for critical medicines that cannot be obtained from the EDC or another ward (as per this policy);
Requests for critical controlled drugs where more than one dose is required before the pharmacy re-opens. Please refer to MSEPO-20237 Controlled Drugs Policy and Procedures;
Requests for critical medicines required to facilitate a safe discharge from
hospital.
All staff must be aware that the oncall service is for critical medication supply or urgent advice only.

The oncall pharmacist is available when all other aspects of this policy (including as summarised by appendix 1) are exhausted. If the oncall pharmacist is contacted when troubleshooting actions have not been attempted they will be signposted to follow this policy.
The oncall pharmacist is unable to undertake a range of tasks which require specialist skills or a second pharmacy check, these include:
Aseptic preparation or manufacture;
Filling of monitored dose systems (e.g. Blister pack/ Dosette boxes);
Dispensing of chemotherapy drugs in most cases (there are limited exceptions in line with local site SOPs);
Dispensing of private prescriptions;
The retail sale of medication.

Staff should note that pharmacist oncall hours are worked in addition to a standard working week. The oncall pharmacist is not based on site and may have to travel a considerable distance to reach the hospital. This will mean that there could be a delay in supply of up to 90 minutes. If a longer time is required to obtain the medicine the pharmacist will inform the requester to determine the appropriate course of action.

Staff contacting the oncall pharmacist must be aware that the pharmacist may be travelling to or from work at the time of the call. For safety when driving calls may not be answered immediately. Staff are kindly requested to call back 10-15mins later.
For medication supply requests, the oncall pharmacist has the authority to advise a suitable, clinically appropriate, alternative or make arrangements to dispense the medicine.

The oncall pharmacist can be contacted (as a last resort, see 7.4 and above) by contacting the hospital site switchboard and asking to be put through to pharmacy oncall. Calls may be made directly via switchboard without the need for consultation with the site manager.
Process for oncall pharmacist attendance on site

If the oncall pharmacist has left the hospital and is unable to remotely deal with the request they will inform the staff member who has made the call of their estimated time back onsite within the hospital site.
If the pharmacist needs to travel into the hospital to make a supply they will agree, in conjunction with the caller, on a suitable time-scale for making the supply.

If after contacting the oncall pharmacist the nurse realises that the medicine is no longer needed, they must inform the pharmacist as soon as possible – via switchboard – to prevent a wasted journey.

The response time is generally around one hour from call to delivery unless the supply has been assessed as a low priority (e.g. dose required later that evening) or where other calls take precedence (e.g. more critical emergency supply is needed).

Where the query or supply issue relates to a specific patient, a staff member from the department/ward where the patient is located should go to the main inpatient pharmacy as agreed with the oncall pharmacist and ring the bell for the inpatient pharmacy dispensary or call the required extension:
Broomfield: A105 (ext.3526) – Ground Floor staff-only corridor behind atrium;
Southend: Ground Floor on the right hand side of the Tower Block Lifts;
Basildon: Level C – doors opposite AMU West.

It is the responsibility of the registered nurse/midwife to ensure that a correctly written drug chart (including Wellsky ePMA where used) exists and is available for the pharmacist. Verbal instructions are not acceptable, and medicines will not be dispensed against these. The ward staff member will need to bring all current paper drug charts (where used) in use to the site pharmacy.

Depending on the length of time the query or supply may take, and/or the workload of the oncall pharmacist, the staff member may be asked to wait, or asked to return to the ward and will be called back when the query or supply is sorted. The pharmacist will not be responsible for arranging porters, if deemed necessary.
Process for when an on-call pharmacist does not need to attend
the hospital

In some cases the pharmacist may not consider it necessary to attend the hospital and using their clinical knowledge will offer advice on alternative strategies to provide patient care until the department re-opens.
Advice for obtaining medicine from another clinical area

9.2.1 Where possible, the pharmacist will advise of a stock of an item held in another clinical area within the hospital. In this situation the contacting nurse/midwife will be instructed to collect the medicines from these areas.

9.2.2 When asked to collect items from another location the requesting nurse must do so quickly and inform the pharmacist immediately if there is a problem so that the pharmacist has the opportunity to decide what action to take.
Supply of Medication to EDC remotely (Broomfield site only)
9.3.1  For the Broomfield site only, the pharmacist has provision to send items from the pharmacy robotic storage system directly to a collection area within the EDC.
Discharge Prescriptions

9.4.1 The oncall pharmacist will not normally attend the hospital to provide specific TTA (to take away) medication unless requested to do so by the site manager at a time of significant bed pressure.
9.4.2 It is the responsibility of ward nursing staff to inform the pharmacy team of planned discharges during the normal working day, and ensure TTA medication is available earlier in the day.
9.4.3 It is not acceptable to call the oncall pharmacist for a prescription which is not required before pharmacy is next open.
Training Requirements
Oncall pharmacist training is delivered face to face within the site pharmacy as part of induction.
There are no specific training needs for other staff, other than familiarising themselves with this policy as part of their induction.

data.text: Approval and Implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by Medicines Assurance Group, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local medication documents. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform all prescribers, nursing and pharmacy of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality Impact Assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
